Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with more or less straight sides; underside decorated with representation of seated cat facing right, with upright tail, sun-disc above back and Maat feather to front; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced through diameter; greenish turquoise glaze poorly preserved; off-white core with porous surface.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). This scaraboid is a product of the Scarab Factory (first published in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 13; on the various productions of the “Scarab Factory”, see Webb forthcoming). It belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A204-212, see especially A205 for this piece). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have only some magical value, it seems more plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun as suggested by Drioton (Drioton 1957, 16, no. 3; see also Hornung and Staehelin 1976, 343, pl. 86, no. 774). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hornung, E., Staehelin, E. 1976. Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 13)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 100, Type XXVIII A205)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.021) (phase 3)
